brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a JetBrains inspection that reports missing Hibernate XML configuration files. It also mentions a quick-fix that creates a facet if necessary and adds a configuration file to it.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'missing-hibernate-config' checks for each XML file in the project. If the file does not exist, it asserts that the file should contain a '<hibernate-configuration>' element. If this assertion fails, it means the Hibernate XML configuration file is missing, and a message is displayed with the name of the missing file.
new_built-in_functions_explanation if an: The rule uses the following built-in functions: getXMLs, pathExists, elementExists, and getName. No new functions were introduced.
PRE_model_validation: The rule seems to be correctly checking for missing Hibernate XML configuration files. It iterates over all XML files in the project, checks if the file exists and if it contains a '<hibernate-configuration>' element. If these conditions are not met, it reports the missing file.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. https://www.baeldung.com/hibernate-5-xml-configuration: This page provides a guide on how to configure Hibernate 5 with XML. It mentions the importance of the '<hibernate-configuration>' element in the XML configuration file.
2. https://www.tutorialspoint.com/hibernate/hibernate_configuration.htm: This tutorial explains how to configure Hibernate using XML. It also emphasizes the necessity of the '<hibernate-configuration>' element in the XML configuration file.
POST_model validation: After reviewing the 3rd-party sources, the rule appears to be valid. Both sources confirm the necessity of the '<hibernate-configuration>' element in the Hibernate XML configuration file. Therefore, the rule correctly checks for this element in each XML file in the project.
